channel.title: CNN.com - Health
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Health
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: 'A' for effort: Teacher transforms
item.description: At his heaviest, high school teacher Jeff Baxter was 465 pounds. Then he lost 270 pounds and went on to become "Teacher of the Year."

item.title: 50 pounds lost for 50th reunion
item.description: In January, Carol Highsmith, 68, began a journey of threes. She had three milestones of 50 that she planned to reach by following three simple rules:

item.title: It's time to get your flu shot!
item.description: Flu season is about to begin, the CDC says. And health officials have a few updates to their recommendations.

item.title: Flu shot myths addressed
item.description: Flu vaccine myths can confuse people trying to decide whether to get a shot. Here are five common myths and, based on information from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the truth.

item.title: Vintage cold and flu ads
Electrodes in brain to treat Tourette's
item.description: A pioneering procedure might be the answer to ending the misery of Tourette's syndrome.

item.title: The next medicinal marijuana?
item.description: Ayahuasca is a psychedelic drink that's attracting more and more tourists to the remote corners of the Amazon. But is it a drug, or is it medicine?

item.title: New link between coffee and DNA
item.description: You can blame that third cup of Joe on your genes.

item.title: Music helps your brain
item.description: Dr. Sanjay Gupta tells us why music therapy is good for the brain and how it can help us live to 100.

item.title: Live to 100: Laugh more
item.description: Dr. Sanjay Gupta tells us how laughing more can help us live to 100.

item.title: Eat chocolate. Yes, chocolate.
item.description: Dr. Sanjay Gupta tell us how eating certain types of chocolate can help us live to 100.

item.title: Visit to Sanjay Gupta's past
item.description: Dr. Sanjay Gupta traveled from Pakistan to Michigan to discover his family's roots. Here's what he learned along the way.

item.title: How to really lose weight
item.description: From what to eat to how much to exercise, Elizabeth Cohen explains what you really need to do to lose weight.

item.title: Keeping young athletes safe
item.description: CNN's Holly Firfer reports on ways parents can keep their student athletes safe.

item.title: Lab holds 2,000 brains
item.description: The University of Miami Brain Endowment Bank provides brain tissues to researchers to study various brain disorders.

item.title: Smart toothbrush tracks brushing
item.description: This Bluetooth enabled toothbrush coaches you while you brush and tracks your progress through a smartphone app.

item.title: Farming in the city
item.description: This urban farm supplies fresh produce to food deserts, but also offers other benefits to individuals and the community.

item.title: Can psychedelic drugs be medicine?
item.description: Psychiatrists are now considering the benefits of LSD and other psychedelic drugs in treatment. Dr. Sanjay Gupta reports.

item.title: What is 'too much' caffeine?
item.description: Carl Azuz reports on why consuming too much caffeine is not good for you.

item.title: Inside your mind with 'Brain Games'
item.description: Jason Silva from National Geographic's hit show "Brain Games" talks about tricks the mind plays that shape our reality.

item.title: The best way to brush
item.description: CNN's Martha Shade reports on what's the best way to brush your teeth.

item.title: How outbreak can start, and end
item.description: Dr. Sanjay Gupta describes how "contact tracing" could help stem the tide of an Ebola outbreak.

item.title: The healthiest fish to eat?
item.description: As our oceans become more polluted, Sally Kohn sits down with Fabien Cousteau to talk about the healthiest fish to eat.

item.title: Plastic surgery gone wrong
item.description: Dr. Terry Dubrow and Dr. Paul Nassif from E!'s new show "Botched" discuss the risks and complications of plastic surgery.

item.title: Ha! Laughter is the best medicine
item.description: Scott Weems, author of "Ha! The Science of When we Laugh and Why," speaks with CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta.

item.title: Twin boys born 24 days apart
item.description: Due to a delayed delivery, a set of twins in Massachusetts were born 24 days apart. WCVB's Mary Saladna reports.

item.title: Is red meat really bad for you?
item.description: CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta talks with Nina Teicholz, author of "The Big Fat Surprise."

item.title: This is your body on weed
item.description: Dr. Sanjay Gupta explains how marijuana affects the brain and how pot can be used to treat certain conditions.

item.title: Teacher eats only McDonald's
item.description: A teacher only eats McDonald's for 90 days, and LOSES 37 pounds. KCCI reports.

item.title: World's most dangerous workout?
item.description: Is the "sport of fitness" the world's most dangerous workout? CNN's Jarrett Bellini asks CrossFitters and gives it a go.

item.title: How to decode the restaurant menu
item.description: Restaurant menus are designed to entice you, not tell you whether the foods are healthy. This guide takes the guesswork out of dining out.

item.title: Athlete achieves dying wish
item.description: Basketball might be a team sport, but Mount St. Joseph University freshman Lauren Hill was clearly the star of the court Sunday in Ohio's Cintas Center in Cincinnati.

item.title: How she lost 145 pounds
item.description: One day, Kari Ianuale had had enough. The Nazareth, Pennsylvania, resident was embarrassed to discover that her size 24 pants no longer fit.

item.title: Special NICU mimics mom's womb
item.description: Doctors and nurses at a specialized unit at CHOC have implemented a system they say is dramatically reducing disability and infection rates among micro preemies.

item.title: How to decode the menu
item.description: Restaurant menus are designed to entice your sense of taste, not tell you whether the foods they're advertising are healthy. This guide takes the guesswork out of dining out.

item.title: How she lost 145 pounds
item.description: One day, Kari Ianuale had had enough. The Nazareth, Pennsylvania, resident was embarrassed to discover that her size 24 pants no longer fit.

item.title: Could Google pill detect cancer?
item.description: Google is developing a pill that would hunt for cancer cells in human bodies. CNN's Laurie Segall reports.

item.title: A one-woman Ebola hospital
item.description: 22-year-old Fatu Kekula nursed her mother, father and sister through Ebola using trash bags to protect herself.

item.title: Crab's blood could save your life
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of horseshoe crabs are captured each year for their incredible blue blood.

item.title: The monster that took my son
item.description: A week before Cole died, I promised him he would do "something big" someday. For two years, I have been fighting to keep that promise.

item.title: Spanish nurse's assistant to leave hospital after beating Ebola
item.description: A Spanish nurse's assistant who caught Ebola while caring for a patient is to be discharged Wednesday after 30 days in the hospital, medical officials said.

item.title: Kaci Hickox: 'The fight is not over'
item.description: Nurse Kaci Hickox has cut a deal with authorities that permits her to travel, more or less freely, while monitoring her health.

item.title: Study: Long-term shift work lessens brain power
item.description: It's not the news that any shift worker wants to hear. Not only is working irregular hours bad for your social life and likely your health, but it has a chronic effect on your ability to think, a new study has found.

item.title: Advocate for 'death with dignity' dies
item.description: Brittany Maynard, the 29-year-old who said she had terminal brain cancer and would end her life under Oregon's "Death with Dignity Act," has died, advocacy group Compassion & Choices said on Facebook.

item.title: Opinion: Who's hurt by assisted suicide?
item.description: Diane Coleman weighs in on Brittany Maynard and the problem with legalizing assisted suicide.

item.title: Scientists link 60 genes to autism risk
item.description: Researchers have found dozens of new genes that may play a role in autism, according to two studies published in the journal Nature.

item.title: 'Lady Ganga': What she did with just a few months to live
item.description: "I had to film her death," Frederic Lumiere says softly. "In the film, I'm behind the camera, and you can hear me crying."

item.title: The diseases lurking in the sewers
item.description: An ambitious project will test sewage for hidden diseases circulating in cities, detecting illnesses people don't even know they have.

item.title: Straighten out smartphone slump!
item.description: As you cradle your smartphone or lean into your laptop to read this, what's your posture like? Even if you aren't doing it right now, how much of your day is spent with your neck lurched forward, shoulders slumped and chest collapsed? All that time in "smartphone slump" not only makes you look and feel stressed, it can cause persistent pain.

item.title: The 5 biggest breakfast myths
item.description: The first meal of the day can have a very different meaning for different people.

item.title: 5 healthy Halloween treats
item.description: We love Halloween season. Sweets. Sweaters. Sipping hot cider (maybe spiked). Halloween can certainly get you in the spirit, and nothing warms our hearts like these healthy Halloween treats that help you stay energized instead of stuck in a sugar coma.

item.title: Reduce your risk of dementia
item.description: The statistics, unfortunately, are staggering. An estimated 44 million people worldwide are living with dementia, according to a report released Tuesday by Alzheimer's Disease International.

item.title: Hallucinogens to treat depression?
item.description: Psychedelic drugs are being researched as a potential treatment for conditions ranging from anxiety to tobacco and alcohol addiction.

item.title: Lack of sleep may shrink your brain
item.description: Can sleep deprivation affect the size of your brain? It's possible, a recent study published in an online issue of Neurology suggests.

item.title: Mental illness: Time to break taboo
item.description: 350 million people around the world suffer from depression. Why aren't we talking about it?

item.title: Schizophrenia is eight disorders
item.description: What we know -- and psychiatrists have diagnosed for decades -- as schizophrenia may really be eight separate diseases, research published in The American Journal of Psychiatry suggests.

item.title: Adam's story: 63 pills a day
item.description: The modest clinic on Milpas Street in laid-back Santa Barbara, California, was well known to patients seeking powerful pain medication.
